raw_results.sampled:
The prime minister raised the subject during talks with US President Barack Obama at the White House. Critics of existing rules say they make the extradition of UK nationals to other countries much harder than it ought to be.
There is also concern among security experts that the rules – designed to protect those accused of a serious crime as far as possible from being extradited to face the prospect of a life sentence if convicted – are now being exploited by criminals.
Under existing rules there is a presumption of a fair extradition process in any country.
But this presumption can be rebutted or removed, however, if it can be shown that a suspect’s life would be at risk if they were extradited.
This is sometimes referred to as the ‘Prisoner Abduction Protocol’ (PAP) and it is a major concern of the authorities as criminals from overseas, often working in gangs of organised criminals, exploit the rules and disappear overseas, knowing they will evade justice.
